module.p: an their is the third person plural possessive determiner, related to the personal pronoun iad they, them.
cf. other uses of the particle an.

section.p:
Some examples –
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr.
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. td. 6

module.p:
Examples from Gairm –
[...] ’Se madainn bhòidheach foghair a bh’ ann—tioram, le ceileir eòin, is beagan dealt air an fheur. Bha a[m] muir ’s na tighean ag éirigh á inntinn an latha. Cha robh e fhéin a’ faireachdainn uabhasach math, oir, air a’ bhàta, bha triùir dhaoine le botul uisge-bheatha agus cha robh càil air a shon ach gu feumadh e òl ’nan cuideachd. [...]
[...] It was a beautiful autumn morning – dry, with the chirping of birds, and a little dew on the grass. The sea and the houses were rising from the mind of the day [??]. He was not feeling terribly good, because, on the boat, there were three men with a bottle of whisky and there was nothing for it but that he would have to drink in their company. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn fused preposition
[...] Cha robh e fhéin a’ faireachdainn uabhasach math, oir, air a’ bhàta, bha triùir dhaoine le botul uisge-bheatha agus cha robh càil air a shon ach gu feumadh e òl ’nan cuideachd. [...] An dràsda ’s a rithist shealladh Iain a-mach air an uinneig ris a’ mhuir ’s na h-eileanan. Chitheadh e aig amannan na faoileagan a’ gabhail seachad, ’s chluinneadh e an cuid sgriachail. Le an amhaichean fada caola ’s an cuirp geala biorach mar chlachan bha iad a’ cur gràin’ air. Theab e an glacadh ’s an lìonadh le uisgebeatha, na biasdan nach gabhadh sàsachadh, na clachan aosd ud, na sgòrnanan ud làn gaoith is sgadain. [...]
[...] He [John] was not feeling terribly good, because, on the boat, there were three men with a bottle of whisky and there was nothing for it but that he would have to drink in their company. [...] Now and again John would look out the window at the sea and the islands. He could see at times the gulls going past, and he could hear their screeching. With their long thin necks and their pointed white bodies like stones they disgusted him. He almost [??] caught them and filled them with whisky, the beasts that cannot be satiated, those ancient stones, those throats full of wind and herring. td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn First example here is not an infinitive. Body parts.

Biblical examples –
[...] A nis dh’éirich righ ùr air an Eiphit, do nach b’aithne Ioseph. Agus thubhairt e r’a shluagh, Feuch, tha sluagh chloinn Israeil ni’s lìonmhoire agus ni’s cumhachdaiche na sinne. Thigibh, buineamaid gu seòlta: an t-eagal gu’m fàs iad lìonmhor, agus gu’n tachair e, ’nuair a dh’éireas cogadh, gu’n gabh iadsan mar an ceudna le ’r naimhdibh-ne, agus gu’n cog iad ’nar n-aghaidh, agus gu’n d’théid iad a mach as an tìr. Uime sin chuir iad maighstirean-oibre orra, chum an sàrachadh le’n eallachaibh. Agus thog iad bailtean-ionmhais do Pharaoh, Pitom agus Raamses. [...]
[...] Now there arose up a new king over Egypt, which knew not Joseph. And he said unto his people, Behold, the people of the children of Israel are more and mightier than we: Come on, let us deal wisely with them; lest they multiply, and it come to pass, that, when there falleth out any war, they join also unto our enemies, and fight against us, and so get them up out of the land. Therefore they did set over them taskmasters to afflict them with their burdens. And they built for Pharaoh treasure cities, Pithom and Raamses. [...] [KJV] Ecsodus I.8–11 fused
[...] Agus thug na h-Eiphitich air cloinn Israeil seirbhis a dheanamh le cruadhas. Agus rinn iad am beatha searbh dhoibh le daorsa chruaidh, ann am moirtear, agus ann an clachaibh-creadha, agus anns gach gnè oibre ’sa’ mhachair: bha an obair uile, anns an d’thug iad orra obair a dheanamh, le cruadhas. [...]
[...] And the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve with rigour: And they made their lives bitter with hard bondage, in morter, and in brick, and in all manner of service in the field: all their service, wherein they made them serve, was with rigour. [...] [KJV] Ecsodus I.13–14

Examples from Gairm –
[...] Dh’fhàs a guth na bu làidir. “Tha aon rud cinnteach, chan fhalbh aon choigreach le mo leanabh. Cha teid i gu aon dannsa, tha sin cinnteach. Tha. Tha. Na bi smaoineachadh gun teid, a leanaibh. Chan eil fhios agad mu ’n deidhinn, mar a th’ agamsa.” “Carson nach do bhàsaich thu o chionn leth-cheud bliadhna,” dh’ éigh Màiri. [...]
[...] Her voice grew louder. “One thing is certain, not one stranger will leave [go out?] with my child. She will not go to a single dance, that is certain. It is. It is. Do not be thinking that you will, child. You don’t know about them, as I do.” “Why didn’t you die fifty years ago,” shouted Mary. [...] td. 169–71, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Biblical examples –
[...] Agus labhair righ na h-Eiphit re mnaibh-glùine nan Eabhruidheach [...] Agus thubhairt e, ’Nuair a ni sibh gnìomh mnà-glùine do na mnaibh Eabhruidheach, agus a chi sibh iad air na stòlaibh; ma’s mac a bhios ann, ’an sin marbhaidh sibh e, ach ma’s nighean a bhios ann, bithidh si beo. Ach bha eagal Dé air na mnaibh-glùine, agus cha d’rinn iad mar a dh’àithn righ na h-Eiphit dhoibh, ach ghleidh iad a’ chlann mhac beo. Agus ghairm righ na h-Eiphit air na mnaibh-glùine, agus thubhairt e riu, C’ar son a rinn sibh an ni so, agus a ghleidh sibh a’ chlann mhac beo? Agus thubhairt na mnài-ghlùine re Pharaoh, A chionn nach ’eil na mnài Eabhruidheach mar na mnài Eiphiteach: oir tha iad féin beothail, agus air an aisead mu’n d’thig na mnài-ghlùine a steach d’an ionnsuidh. Uime sin bhuin Dia gu math ris na mnaibh-glùine: agus rinneadh an sluagh lìonmhor, agus dh’fhàs iad ro-chumhachdach. [...]
[...] And the king of Egypt spake to the Hebrew midwives [...] And he said, When ye do the office of a midwife to the Hebrew women, and see them upon the stools; if it be a son, then ye shall kill him: but if it be a daughter, then she shall live. But the midwives feared God, and did not as the king of Egypt commanded them, but saved the men children alive. And the king of Egypt called for the midwives, and said unto them, Why have ye done this thing, and have saved the men children alive? And the midwives said unto Pharaoh, Because the Hebrew women are not as the Egyptian women; for they are lively, and are delivered ere the midwives come in unto them. Therefore God dealt well with the midwives: and the people multiplied, and waxed very mighty. [...] Ecsodus I.15–20

Anns na ràithean ’s na bliadhnachan a tha air thoiseach oirnn, tha fhios gun dig iomadh atharrachadh air Roinn na Gàidhlig sa’ Bh.B.C. [...] Mar a bhios obair a’ Bh.B.C. a’ leudachadh anns a’ Ghaidhealtachd—agus tha fhios gun tachair so leis na stéiseanan ùra a thathas a’ togail—bithidh sùil againn ri daoine ùra ’s ri dòighean ùra. Bhitheadh e nàdurrach agus fallain nam biodh barrachd phrógraman air an deilbh air a’ Ghaidhealtachd fhéin, agus gum biodh pàirt de ’n obair so air a chur an tairgse nan Gaidheal ’s nan Gall air Galldachd. [...]
During the seasons and the years that are ahead of us, it is known that many changes will come to the Gaelic Department of the BBC. [...] As the work of the BBC will be expanding in the Highlands – and it is known that this will happen with the new stations that are being established – we will be expecting new people and new methods. It would be natural and healthy if more programmes were produced in the Highlands itself, and [if] part of this work were offered to Gaels and non-Gaels in the Lowlands. [...] td. 297, ‘Air an Spiris’ passive

Examples from Gairm –
Anns na ràithean ’s na bliadhnachan a tha air thoiseach oirnn, tha fhios gun dig iomadh atharrachadh air Roinn na Gàidhlig sa’ Bh.B.C. [...] Bithidh cuideachadh a dhìth air luchd a’ Bh.B.C., agus ’se an cuideachadh a b’ fheàrr a b’ urrainn dhuinn a thoirt dhaibh ar n-ùidh a nochdadh, le bhith a’ sgrìobhadh thuca, gam moladh is gan càineadh, ag iarraidh tuilleadh tìde do ’n Ghàidhlig, is a’ sealltainn dhaibh gu bheil sinn a’ dèanamh feum de ’n tìde a th’ againn.
During the seasons and the years that are ahead of us, it is known that many changes will come to the Gaelic Department of the BBC. [...] The BBC people will need help, and the best help that we can give them is to show them our interest, by writing to them, praising them and criticising them, demanding more time for Gaelic, and showing them that we are making use of the time that we have. td. 297, ‘Air an Spiris’
[...] Chaidil e airson greiseag ’s nuair a dhùisg e anns a’ mhadainn bha a bheul salach le blas an uisge-bheatha. Choisich e mach ás a’ bhàta a-measg nam faoileagan, ga[n] sguabadh air falbh le a làmhan, agus lean e air suas an aon rathad a bh’ ann gus an ruigeadh e an tigh. [...]
[...] He slept for a bit and when he woke up in the morning his mouth was dirty with the taste of the whisky. He walked out of the boat among the gulls, brushing them away with his hands, and he continued up the only road that there was until he reached the house. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
“’Se Sasunnach a bh’ ann,” ars ise le prois, [...] “Cha robh e ach fichead bliadhna a dh’ aois. Balach àrd tapaidh le léine shìoda. Thubhairt e rium gum pòsadh e mi.” [...] “Thainig e mach á sgoth-luing le na siùil gheala. Cha robh facal Gàidhlig aige.” Rinn i gàire thioram mar dà phaipeir-ghainmheach ga[n] suathadh ri chéile. [...]
“He was an Englishman,” she said with pride, [...] “He was just twenty years of age. A tall strong boy with a silk shirt. He said to me that he would marry me.” “He came out of a yacht with white sails. He didn’t have a word of Gaelic.” She made a dry laugh like two sheets of sandpaper being rubbed against each other. [...] td. 170, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn passive
